sn36.11:2.1: The Buddha praises the mendicant because he had the critical acumen to notice these apparently different explanations, and, rather than assuming they were contradictory, or just ignoring the problem, he asked the Buddha for clarification. Compare the Buddha’s quite different response at SN 36.19:5.1.
sn36.11:2.15: The “progressive cessation of activities” (anupubbasaṅkhārānaṁ nirodho), and their “settling” (vūpasama) and “tranquilizing” (passaddhi) are only mentioned here, SN 36.15, and SN 36.17. Compare the nine “progressive cessations” of AN 9.31 and DN 33:3.2.82, but these go even further to full enlightenment, as in the “progressive cessation in a definitive sense” at AN 9.61. | “Activities” (saṅkhārā) are the conditioned phenomena that are active, being both produced by and productive of other conditions. Here they are the “processes” that are stilled in the course of meditation.
sn36.11:2.31: This is the same at the corresponding point in SN 36.17:2.7, but at  SN 36.15:1.22 it speaks of the “progressive tranquilizing of activities”.
